bioghist.p: Prior to 1913 the City of Philadelphia's relations with public transit companies were administered through the offices of the City Surveyor and the Bureau of Highways under the general supervision of Councils' Committee on Street Railroads. In that year, under an Act approved on 9 May 1913, the Department of City Transit was established to coordinate the control of all transit facilities located within the City with especial regard to the contract of 1907 between the City and the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company formed in that year as an amalgamation of the many transit companies that had existed independently until that time. Dr. Harold E. Cox is professor and chair of the department of history at Wilkes University, Pennsylvania. He is the former editor of Pennsylvania History and has written extensively on the history of urban transportation and the development of inner cities in the nineteenth century.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of records of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit and subsidiary and predecessor companies. Bound volumes include: passenger statistics; accident reports; minutes; financial volumes; stock ledgers; annual reports; and letterbooks. Correspondence files (1896-1912) in the collection include: incoming and outgoing correspondence; telegrams; internal memoranda; copies of legal documents and leases; and clippings. Correspondence relates to financial matters, rate changes, labor relations and disputes, and rate inquiries from passengers. Other correspondence is with suppliers and companies with which PRT did business. A small amount of correspondence is related to the purchasing of rolling stock. Legal files in the collection include: reports, filings, hearings, and other materials related to rate increases, equipment leases, ordnances, charters, and reorganization. Cases involve PRT's interactions with Philadelphia Public Utilities Commission and the City of Philadelphia. Reports and memoranda from the 1920s-1950s, include: information on war-time preparations and activities (1941-1945); notices to employees, 1911-1939; a small amount of materials related to the Engineering Department, including contract plans, specifications, maps, and general internal and external correspondence; Plant Accounting annual reports on the company's assets; and stockholder lists for PRT and subsidiary and predecessor companies. Other materials in the collection include: bound volumes of "Off-Peak", employee newsletter, 1942-1948; 16 reels of microfilm of electrical diagrams, car details, conduit plans, bridges and other structures; large format published maps of Philadelphia; PRT route map (1925); plan for transit development (1926), and Philadelphia ward atlases published by G. W. Bromley & Co. and Elvino V. Smith. Bound volumes of PRT and PTC publications (1919-1934) include schedules, brochures, maps, telephone directories, notices to stockholders, annual reports, letters and notices to employees, procedure manuals, event programs, stockholder resolutions, route guides, and safety first publications. Scrapbooks in the collection include: 33 scrapbooks of newspaper clippings, in chronological order (some volumes are numbered and there are some gaps), 1902-1912; 23 scrapbooks meticulously kept by Edmund Stirling, an index, and 5 volumes of bound pamphlets, 1917-1929, also arranged by Stirling; and a J. G. Brill Company photograph album of "Specialties". Materials in the collection related to the Willow Grove Amusement Park include: journals (1897-1906) and cashbooks (1896-1897 and 1904-1911); Willow Grove scrapbook, 1907; and a plan of Willow Grove. There is also a small mount of correspondence related to entertainment and concessions at Willow Grove Park. Additional published materials in the collection include: Public Ledger almanacs (1874-1899); Geography of the State of Pennsylvania, (1843); The Law Adopting Certain Township Roads as State Highways Passed at the session of 1931; The Chronicles of Middletown (1906); Washington's Farewell Address (1856); and The Family Almanac (1884). There are also nineteen 19th century pamphlets related to rail roads, the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company, prisons, and the Philadelphia school district, among other things. Most of these are annual reports or agreements.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
